transcripts.text: Here's PragerU to completely misunderstand the First Amendment.

Almost everyone has heard of the doctrine of the separation of church and state.  Most Americans believe that it's in the United States Constitution.  But there is no such phrase in the Constitution, and there never was, for a simple reason.  The Founding Fathers never intended for church and state to be completely separate.  They saw religion, specifically religions based on the Bible, as indispensable to the moral foundation of the nation they were creating.
Citation needed, but even if that's the case, the nation and the state are two different things.

So where does that phrase come from?  It comes from one brief letter that Thomas Jefferson wrote to the Danbury Baptist Association in 1802.  At the end of a very long sentence in which Jefferson affirms his conviction that religious belief should be a private matter and that the government should not interfere with such matters, he uses the phrase, "...building a wall of separation between church and  state.".  And that's where the phrase lived, undisturbed, lost in Jefferson's voluminous correspondence for almost 150 years.

So, was Thomas Jefferson not a founding father?  The full sentence is, Believing with you that religion is a matter which lies solely between man and his God, that he owes account to none other for his faith or his worship, that the legitimate powers of government reach actions only and not opinions, I contemplate with sovereign reverence that act of the whole American people which declared that their legislature... should make no law respecting an establishment of religion or prohibiting the free exercise thereof, thus building a wall of separation between church and state.  Jefferson believed that building a wall between church and state was the whole point of the Establishment Clause of the First Amendment.

But more on that in a moment.  First, let's discuss what the Constitution actually does say about religion and its role in public life.  The answer is found in the First Amendment to the Constitution.  Congress shall make no law respecting an establishment of religion or prohibiting the free exercise thereof.
Which is precisely what at least one founding father believed to be a separation of church and state.

It's plain what those words mean.  The federal government could not establish a national religion, the common practice in Europe.  The United States was going to be different.  Americans would be free to follow the religion of their choice.  When James Madison first proposed what eventually became the First Amendment, his original wording was that no religion shall be established by Congress.  But that language was later modified after it was pointed out that this might be taken to mean that the government, including the state governments, had no interest in religion at all.

It's true that originally the First Amendment, in fact the whole Bill of Rights, only applied to Congress.  But then along came the 14th Amendment, which says, "...no state shall make or enforce any law which shall abridge the privileges or immunities of citizens of the United  States.".  Courts have interpreted this to mean that if Congress can't force religion on people by establishing an official one, neither can the states.
The founders did not want this.  As George Washington said in his farewell address, religion and morality are indispensable supports of our political prosperity.
This statement in no way says that the government therefore ought to be permitted to support it with taxpayers' money.

Washington's view remained the nation's view throughout the 19th century and into the 20th, but that changed in 1947.  In that year, in the case of Everson v. Board of Education, the Supreme Court ruled in a 5-4 decision that under the First Amendment, neither a state nor the federal government could pass laws which aid one religion, aid all religions, or prefer one religion over another.
That didn't really change in 1947.  It changed in 1868 when the 14th Amendment, upon which Everson is based, was ratified.

For the first time in American history, the First Amendment was not only about the prohibition of establishing a national religion, it was also about not giving any encouragement to any religion.  The modern strict separation view was born.
No, it was born at the latest when Jefferson had that view and expressed it in his letter to Danbury in 1802.
And where did the five justices look for support for their argument?  Not the Constitution, because there was nothing in the Constitution to help them.
So they just cited the First and Fourteenth Amendments.  for no reason then?

But to that one phrase Thomas Jefferson wrote back in 1802, How ironic that the author of the Declaration of Independence, which recognizes the proposition that human beings have inalienable rights from their creator and not from government, was now being used to separate religion from the public square.

First of all, the Declaration of Independence is not the Constitution.  And secondly, the fact that something comes from a creator and not from the government underscores the idea that the two are distinct.  This phrase does not help your case.  And keep in mind that Jefferson was also the author of the Virginia Statute of Religious Freedom.  which states that no man shall be compelled to frequent or support any religious worship place or ministry whatsoever, nor shall be enforced, restrained, or burthened in his body or goods, nor shall otherwise suffer on account of his religious opinions or belief, but that all men shall be free to profess and by argument to maintain their opinions in matters of religion.  and that the same shall in no wise diminish, enlarge, or affect their civil capacities.  In other words, Jefferson opposed any law that put one single penny of taxpayers' money toward providing any support whatsoever to anything even remotely religious.

For Jefferson and the other founders, religion was central to the entire American project.  The Declaration of Independence and the Constitution are just two of countless examples where the government acknowledges its debt to God.

What does that mean specifically?  The word God does not appear in the Constitution.  And even if a debt to God were acknowledged, that in no way means that they believe that supporting religion is therefore something that should ever be the government's job.

As the famously liberal Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas wrote in the case of Zorach v. Clausen just five years after the Everson decision, we are a religious people whose institutions presuppose a supreme being.  The founders would certainly have agreed.
Presupposing a supreme being and supporting the worship of one are two different things.
Following Everson, the nation's moral infrastructure began to crack, at first slowly and then more rapidly.
Yeah, the moral infrastructure was so much more sound in the days before Everson when segregation was still allowed and gay marriage was not.

In 1962, the Supreme Court struck another blow.  It ruled in Engel v. Vitale that a generic school prayer violated the court's new definition of the First Amendment.  Listen to the words of that school prayer.
According to at least one founding father, that's not something that taxpayers' money should be used to pay teachers to say.
The prayer was not specific to Christianity or to any religion.
That doesn't matter.  I agree with Jefferson that not a single penny of taxpayers' money ought to be spent on paying anyone to say a prayer of any kind.
Since then, the separation of church and state metaphor has been used to remove God and religion piece by piece from American public life.
If by public life you mean anything the government does, then that's exactly what at least one founding father endorsed.

Are we a better society for it?  It's hard to argue that we are.  Almost every cultural and ethical indicator—marriage rates, birth rates, the number of Americans giving to charity—has declined since God and religion have faded from American life.
And crime rates have dropped steadily since the founding of the band Chicks Dig It.  Surely neither of these correlations could be a coincidence.

Meanwhile, children without fathers in their lives, behavioral problems in schools, and crime have gone up dramatically.  And all because of one vote in one court case based on one sentence in one letter.

That's all it took, folks.  No need to look at complex socioeconomic variables, or the fact that crime rates are as low now as they were in the 50s.  Nope, all these problems, both real and imagined, are all because of the fact that kids don't hear their teachers pray anymore.  To everyone who helps me out on Patreon, you're a big help.
